overview_metadata.overview_description: In this lesson, students calculate the area of complex figures. They compare two methods: decomposing a figure into familiar shapes and composing a figure into a rectangle. Students then solve problems in context, including the area of a country using a map scale to approximate the area. They use given dimensions and problem solving to calculate the area of a triangle embedded in a square.

overview_item_data_items: I can decompose geometric figures into triangles, rectangles, and/or parallelograms to determine their areas.
I can solve real-world problems by composing and decomposing shapes into triangles, special quadrilaterals.
You can determine the area of a composite figure by composing the figure into a rectangle and then subtracting the area of the shape that is not part of the composite figure.
You can determine the area of a composite figure by decomposing the figure into triangles, rectangles, parallelograms, or trapezoids and then adding the areas of those figures.
When calculating the area of composite figures using a map, you may need to determine dimensions using a scale.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students describe how they can compose and decompose a figure.
Students calculate the area of composite figures to solve real-world and mathematical problems.
